contentItemData.label: Documentation Index
contentItemData.description: Provides an overview and hyperlinks to all packaged documentation.

contentItemData.label: UG103-06: Bootloading Fundamentals
contentItemData.description: Introduces bootloading for Silicon Labs networking devices. Discusses the Gecko Bootloader as well as legacy Ember and Bluetooth bootloaders, and describes the file formats used by each.

contentItemData.label: AN1085: Using the Gecko Bootloader with Silicon Labs Connect
contentItemData.description: Includes detailed information on using the Silicon Labs Gecko Bootloader with Connect. It supplements the general Gecko Bootloader implementation information provided in UG266: Silicon Labs Gecko Bootloader User's Guide.

contentItemData.label: UG103-12: Connect Fundamentals
contentItemData.description: Describes the features and functions of the Silicon Labs Connect stack, including its device types, network topologies, and its 'building block' development methodology using plugins.

contentItemData.label: Silicon Labs RAIL API Reference Guide
contentItemData.description: Contains a comprehensive list of APIs used to interface to the Silicon Labs RAIL library.

contentItemData.label: AN1153: Developing Connect vNCP Applications with Micrium OS
contentItemData.description: Describes how the Silicon Labs Flex SDK provides support for running the Connect stack on top of the Micrium OS kernel.

contentItemData.label: AN844: Host/Network Co-Processor Communications Using Silicon Labs Thread and Connect
contentItemData.description: Describes how to set up and test UART communication between a host and Network Co-Processor (NCP) using ASHv3-UART. You should have a Raspberry Pi, USB cable (for UART communication), and a development board.

contentItemData.label: Silicon Labs Connect API Reference Guide
contentItemData.description: Contains a comprehensive list of APIs used to interface to the Silicon Labs Connect stack.

contentItemData.label: AN703: Using Simulated EEPROM Version 1 and Version 2 for the EM35x and EFR32 SoC Platforms
contentItemData.description: Describes how to use the simulated EEPROM in Silicon Labs' EM35x and Mighty Gecko (EFR32MG) platforms, gives an overview of the internal design, and discusses design considerations. You should already be familiar with the token system in the HAL. For more information on HAL and the token system, see the online HAL API documentation.

contentItemData.label: UG103-01: Wireless Networking Fundamentals
contentItemData.description: Introduces some fundamental concepts of wireless networking. These concepts are referred to in other Fundamentals documents. If you are new to wireless networking, you should read this document first.

contentItemData.label: AN972: EFR32 RF Evaluation Guide
contentItemData.description: Describes using RAILTest to evaluate radio functionality, as well as peripherals, deep sleep states, etc. With it you can fully evaluate the receiving and transmitting performance and test RF functionality of development kit hardware or custom hardware.

contentItemData.label: UG103-13: RAIL Fundamentals
contentItemData.description: Describes the features and functions of Silicon Labs RAIL (Radio Abstraction Interface Layer). RAIL provides an intuitive, easily-customizable radio interface layer that is designed to support proprietary or standards-based wireless protocols.

contentItemData.label: AN902: Building Low Power Networks with the Silicon Labs Connect Stack
contentItemData.description: Illustrates techniques using the Silicon Labs Connect stack to reduce power consumption in a sensor network developed using the Silicon Labs Connect Stack.

contentItemData.label: UG115: ASHv3 Protocol Reference
contentItemData.description: Describes the protocol used by the UART-based ASHv3 to carry commands and responses reliably between a host processor and a network co-processor.

contentItemData.label: QSG155: Using the Silicon Labs Dynamic Multiprotocol Demonstrations
contentItemData.description: Shows how to demonstrate Dynamic Multiprotocol functionality using a Bluetooth LE smartphone app with either Zigbee-Bluetooth or RAIL-Bluetooth demo applications.

contentItemData.label: QSG138: Getting Started with the Silicon Labs Flex SDK for the Wireless Gecko (EFR32) Portfolio
contentItemData.description: For the EFR32 portfolio, provides basic information on configuring, building, and installing applications using the Silicon Labs Flex SDK, which offers two paths to application development. One, using Silicon Labs Connect, provides a fully-featured, easily-customizable wireless networking solution. The other begins with Silicon Labs RAIL (Radio Abstraction Interface Layer), and offers a customizable radio interface layer designed to support proprietary or standards-based wireless protocols.

contentItemData.label: AN1154: Using Tokens for Non-Volatile Data Storage
contentItemData.description: Describes tokens and shows how to use them for non-volatile data storage in EmberZNet PRO, Silicon Labs Flex, and Silicon Labs Thread applications.

contentItemData.label: Flex SDK Release Notes
contentItemData.description: Lists compatibility requirements and sources for all software componentsin the development environment. Discusses the latest changes to the SiliconLabs Flex SDK, including added/deleted/deprecated features/API. Reviews bugs that have been fixed since the last release, and any pending ones. Intended for project managers and software developers.

contentItemData.label: AN1115: Configuring Peripherals for 32-Bit Devices in Simplicity Studio
contentItemData.description: Describes how to initialize and customize peripherals for 32-bit devices, both in the Simplicity IDE and using the standalone Hardware Configurator tool.

contentItemData.label: AN971: EFR32 Radio Configurator Guide
contentItemData.description: Describes the radio configurator GUI for RAIL framework applications. With it, you can create standard or custom radio configurations on which to run your RAIL-based applications. The role of each GUI item is explained.

contentItemData.label: UG235: Silicon Labs Connect User Guide
contentItemData.description: Provides in-depth information for developers using the Silicon Labs Connect stack as a foundation for their application development on the Wireless Gecko (EFR32) portfolio or custom hardware. The Connect stack is delivered as part of the Silicon Labs Flex SDK. You should have already installed the Simplicity Studio development environment and the Flex SDK, and be familiar with the basics of configuring, compiling, and flashing Connect-based applications.

contentItemData.label: AN1127: Power Amplifier Power Conversion Functions in RAIL 2.x
contentItemData.description: Outlines how to account for the variation in output characteristics across custom boards and applications for the Silicon Labs EFR32 family of chips.

contentItemData.label: UG103-03: Design Choices Fundamentals
contentItemData.description: Discusses the major decisions to be made about architecting a wireless networking solution, as well as additional decisions to be made if you are designing a ZigBee solution.

contentItemData.label: UG103-07: Non-Volatile Data Storage Fundamentals
contentItemData.description: Introduces non-volatile data storage using flash and the three different storage implementations offered for Silicon Labs microcontrollers and SoCs: Simulated EEPROM, PS Store, and NVM3.

contentItemData.label: UG103-16: Multiprotocol Fundamentals
contentItemData.description: Describes the four multiprotocol modes, discusses considerations when selecting protocols for multiprotocol implementations, and reviews the Radio Scheduler, a required component of a dynamic multiprotocol solution.

contentItemData.label: UG266: Silicon Labs Gecko Bootloader User's Guide
contentItemData.description: Describes the high-level implementation of the Silicon Labs Gecko Bootloader for EFR32 SoCs and NCPs, and provides information on how to get started using the Gecko Bootloader with Silicon Labs wireless protocol stacks.

contentItemData.label: AN1113: Porting RAIL Applications to RAIL Version 2.0
contentItemData.description: Describes the main drivers for RAIL 2.0 and key programmatic considerations when porting an application from RAIL 1.6 to RAIL 2.0.

contentItemData.label: UG147: Flex Gecko 2.4 GHz, 20 dBm Range Test Demo Users Guide
contentItemData.description: Provides an easy way to evaluate the link budget of the Wireless Gecko EFR32 devices using Silicon Labs RAIL (RAIL) by performing a range test between two nodes using Range Test, a standalone test application. The range test demo implements Packet Error Rate (PER) measurement.

contentItemData.label: UG162: Simplicity Commander Reference Guide
contentItemData.description: Describes how and when to use Simplicity Commander's Command-Line Interface. Only EFR32 is currently supported. EM3xx is not supported at this time.

contentItemData.label: Using RAIL Test
contentItemData.description: Describes the functionality available in the RAILTest application.

contentItemData.label: AN1119: Using RAIL for Wireless M-Bus Applications with EFR32
contentItemData.description: Describes using the Flex SDK for Wireless M-Bus development on EFR32 Wireless Geckos. Includes features and limitations as well as examples.
